0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-lawsuit-idUSKCN10M2KG	Trump settles legal dispute with former campaign aide	"
Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's campaign has settled a legal dispute with former aide Sam Nunberg
column2: according to a court document filed in New York on Thursday.Trump had sought $10 million in damages from Nunberg in arbitration proceedings. Trump accused Nunberg
column3: who was fired in 2015
column4: of violating a confidentiality agreement.The one-page filing with a New York state court did not give the terms of the settlement.Nunberg's attorney
column5: Andrew Miltenberg
column6: said ""the matter was amicably resolved"" but he declined to comment further. The Trump campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

column1: Nunberg said in court filings in July that Trump accused him of being the source for a New York Post story in May that recounted a public argument between Corey Lewandowski
column2: who was then the campaign manager
column3: and Hope Hicks
column4: Trump's spokeswoman.In the affidavit
column5: Nunberg said the argument was part of a ""sordid and apparently illicit affair"" between the two. He denied being the source for the New York Post story.

column1: Lewandowski was fired by the campaign in June
column2: a move apparently unrelated to the Post story. A Trump Organization lawyer
column3: Alan Garten
column4: last month called Nunberg's allegations ""categorically untrue.""

column1: The Trump campaign fired Nunberg in August 2015 after the discovery of Facebook posts that critics deemed racist. Nunberg has denied he wrote the posts. (Reporting by Eric Beech in Washington; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Trump']	[]
1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-vaccines-idUSKCN10M20K	U.S. government shifts $81 million to Zika vaccine research	"
By Julie Steenhuysen and Toni Clarke
| CHICAGO/WASHINGTON

CHICAGO/WASHINGTON The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services has shifted $81 million in funds from other projects to continue work on developing vaccines to fight Zika in the absence of any funding from U.S. lawmakers.In a letter addressed to Nancy Pelosi
column2: a Democrat and minority leader of the U.S. House of Representatives
column3: HHS Secretary Sylvia Burwell said she was allocating $34 million in funding to the National Institutes of Health and $47 million to the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) to work on Zika vaccines.Burwell said the funding was intended to keep Zika vaccine research going despite the lack of funding from U.S. lawmakers
column4: who left for summer recess before allocating any funding to Zika research and preparedness.The mosquito-borne Zika virus has spread to more than 50 countries and territories since the outbreak began last year in Brazil. On Thursday
column5: Governor Rick Scott said state health officials have identified three additional people in the affected area with locally transmitted Zika
column6: bringing the total to 25.The Obama administration in February requested $1.9 billion to fight Zika
column7: but congressional lawmakers have been considering a much smaller sum. A bill providing $1.1 billion was blocked by Democrats after Republicans attached language to stop abortion-provider Planned Parenthood from using that government funding for healthcare services
column8: mainly in U.S. territories like Puerto Rico.The Republican legislation also would siphon off unused money under President Barack Obama's signature 2010 healthcare law to combat Zika. In addition
column9: Democrats balked at a Republican provision that they said would gut clean water protections.The new bolus of funds from HHS comes on top of the $589 million in repurposed funds previously allocated for Ebola efforts. HHS has said these funds will run out at the end of August.

column1: At a press briefing in Washington
column2: Dr. Anthony Fauci
column3: director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
column4: said he needs $33 million to prepare to move the first potential Zika vaccine to the second phase of human clinical trials. The first phase of that testing is expected to end in late November or December.Fauci said the health secretary has the authority to transfer 1 percent of NIH's $33 billion budget per year from one Institute to the other. He said the director of the NIH
column5: Dr. Francis Collins
column6: will decide which existing programs the funds will be drawn from.""He will probably do it on a prorated basis across the Institutes
column7: he said.

column1: Fauci said the budget transfer will not fill the longer-term NIH funding needs to fight the virus and to develop a second or third potential vaccine candidate. Drugs frequently fail to realize the promise they show in early trials.""We still need about $196 million more
column2: he said.Fauci said the health secretary's action was essentially one of desperation given the failure of Congress to authorize additional funding.Taking money from other research programs ""is extremely damaging to the biomedical research enterprise
column3: he said. ""We're taking money away from cancer
column4: diabetes
column5: all those things.""

column1: Dr. LaMar Hasbrouck
column2: executive director of the National Association of County and City Health Officials
column3: said at the briefing that local health authorities are similarly siphoning off money from other programs.""We're robbing Peter to pay Paul
column4: he said. In her letter
column5: Burwell said the $47 million in funding for BARDA will allow the agency to enter into contracts with key partners to develop vaccines. But
column6: she said BARDA will need an   estimated $342 million in additional funding to continue its work with outside partners in the development of vaccines
column7: diagnostics and pathogen inactivation technology used to protect the U.S. blood supply. (Reporting by Julie Steenhuysen in Chicago and Toni Clarke in Washington; editing by Grant McCool and Bernard Orr)"	['Clarke'
column8: 'Obama']	['healthcare']

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-qanda-factbox-idUSKCN10M2HP	Factbox: Why the Zika virus is causing alarm	"

Global health officials are racing to better understand the Zika virus behind a major outbreak that began in Brazil last year and has spread to many countries in the Americas. The following are some questions and answers about the virus and current outbreak:How do people become infected?Zika is transmitted to people through the bite of infected female mosquitoes
column2: primarily the Aedes aegypti mosquito
column3: the same type that spreads dengue
column4: chikungunya and yellow fever. The Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) said Aedes mosquitoes are found in all countries in the Americas except Canada and continental Chile
column5: and the virus will likely reach all countries and territories of the region where Aedes mosquitoes are found.How do you treat Zika?There is no treatment or vaccine for Zika infection. Companies and scientists are racing to develop a safe and effective vaccine for Zika
column6: but the World Health Organization (WHO) had said early in 2016 that it would take at least 18 months to start large-scale clinical trials of potential preventative shots.A vaccine is not expected to be ready for widespread use for at least two or three years. U.S. government researchers said they started their first clinical trial of a Zika vaccine.How dangerous is it?The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention concluded that infection with the Zika virus in pregnant women is a cause of the birth defect microcephaly and other severe brain abnormalities in babies. The CDC said now that the causal relationship has been established
column7: several important questions must still be answered with studies that could take years.According to the World Health Organization
column8: there is strong scientific consensus that Zika can cause the birth defect microcephaly in babies
column9: a condition defined by unusually small heads that can result in developmental problems. In addition
column10: the agency said it could cause Guillain-Barre syndrome
column11: a rare neurological disorder that can result in paralysis. Conclusive proof of the damage caused by Zika may take months or years.Brazil reports the number of confirmed cases of microcephaly at more than 1
column12: 700 as doctors and Brazilian health officials find that some suspected cases of microcephaly are not the disorder. Suspected ones under investigation had declined to 3
column14: 387 likely cases of the Zika virus from February until April 2.Current research in Brazil indicates the greatest microcephaly risk is associated with infection during the first trimester of pregnancy
column15: but health officials have warned an impact could be seen in later weeks. Recent studies have shown evidence of Zika in amniotic fluid

column1: What are the symptoms of Zika infection?    People infected with Zika may have a mild fever
column2: skin rash
column3: conjunctivitis
column4: muscle and joint pain and fatigue that can last for two to seven days. But as many as 80 percent of people infected never develop symptoms. The symptoms are similar to those of dengue or chikungunya
column5: which are transmitted by the same type of mosquito.How can Zika be contained?Efforts to control the spread of the virus focus on eliminating mosquito breeding sites and taking precautions against mosquito bites such as using insect repellent and mosquito nets. U.S. and international health officials have advised pregnant women to avoid travel to Latin American and Caribbean countries where they may be exposed to Zika.How widespread is the outbreak?

column1: Active Zika outbreaks have been reported in at least 54 countries or territories
column2: most of them in the Americas
column3: according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Brazil has been the country most affected. (1.usa.gov/1ovAJyh)Africa (1): Cape Verde Americas (45): Anguilla
column4: Antigua
column5: Argentina
column6: Aruba
column7: Barbados
column8: Barbuda
column46: U.S. Virgin Islands and Venezuela.Oceania/Pacific Islands (8): American Samoa
column54: and Tonga. What is the history of the Zika virus?The Zika virus is found in tropical locales with large mosquito populations. Outbreaks of Zika have been recorded in Africa
column56: Southern Asia and the Western Pacific. The virus was first identified in Uganda in 1947 in rhesus monkeys and was first identified in people in 1952 in Uganda and Tanzania

column1: Can Zika be transmitted through sexual contact?The World Health Organization (WHO) said sexual transmission is ""relatively common"" and has advised pregnant women not to travel to areas with ongoing outbreaks of Zika virus. It also  advised women living in areas where the virus is being transmitted to delay getting pregnant.The U.S. CDC is investigating about a dozen cases of possible sexual transmission. Those cases involved possible transmission of the virus from men to their sex partners.But the CDC issued updated recommendations for preventing and testing for Zika infection on July 25
column2: warning that the virus can be transmitted through unprotected sex with an infected female partner.A reported case of female-to-male sexual transmission in New York City
column3: and limited human and non-human primate data indicating that Zika virus RNA can be detected in vaginal secretions
column4: led to the new warning
column5: the agency said.CDC's expanded warnings on sexual exposure to Zika now  caution against sex without a condom or other barrier method of protection with any person
column6: male or female
column7: who has traveled to or lives in an area with Zika
column8: including female to female transmission with a pregnant partner.British health officials reported Zika was found in a man's semen two months after he was infected
column9: suggesting the virus may linger in semen long after infection symptoms fade.The PAHO said Zika can be transmitted through blood
column10: but this is an infrequent transmission mechanism. There is no evidence Zika can be transmitted to babies through breast milk.The WHO has identified Zika cases in Argentina
column13: Italy and New Zealand as likely caused by sexual transmission. What other complications are associated with Zika?Zika has also been associated with other neurological disorders
column14: including serious brain and spinal cord infections. The long-term health consequences of Zika infection are unclear. Other uncertainties surround the incubation period of the virus and how Zika interacts with other viruses that are transmitted by mosquitoes
column15: such as dengue. (Compiled by the Americas Desk)"	['Costa']	[]

column11: among newbornsNov. 11: Brazil declares public health emergency November 2015-January 2016: Cases reported in Suriname

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-evangelicals-idUSKCN10M2D4	Trump acknowledges tough fight in usually Republican Utah	"
By Steve Holland
| ORLANDO
column2: Fla.

column1: ORLANDO
column2: Fla. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump acknowledged on Thursday that his campaign was struggling in Utah
column3: a usually rock-solid Republican state
column4: on a day in which he briefly set aside his self-confidence for a rare display of doubt. Trump made the comment in urging conservative Christian evangelicals to organize support for him in several key states where the Nov. 8 election is likely to be decided
column5: such as Ohio
column6: Florida and Virginia.The wealthy New York businessman has suffered a number of self-inflicted wounds in recent days that have given the advantage in the campaign to Democrat Hillary Clinton.""We're having a tremendous problem in Utah
column7: Trump told a conference room filled with evangelical pastors
column8: blaming a ""false narrative"" that has been built up around his candidacy. He has repeatedly blamed the news media for dishonest tactics.A SurveyUSA opinion poll conducted for the Salt Lake Tribune in June showed Clinton and Trump tied. Other polls have given Trump a lead but not the type of advantage that previous Republican nominees have enjoyed in the state.The normally confident Trump never apologizes and is loathe to admit that he might face difficulties. But in talking to the National Association of Home Builders earlier in Miami Beach
column9: Trump admitted his past years before he became a politician could be causing him problems now.""If I had planned for it
column10: I wouldn't have had such a rocky path
column11: he said. ""I wouldn't have spoken to Howard so much.""

column1: That was a reference to his many appearances on the ""Howard Stern Show"" radio program. He has been estimated to have appeared on the show more than two dozen times over 20 years
column2: and the conversation frequently turned ribald. Trump
column3: who is trailing Clinton in Virginia
column4: a formerly Republican state that Democratic President Barack Obama won in 2008 and 2012
column5: urged evangelicals to help him in that state as well.In doing so
column6: Trump pledged to rewrite the so-called Johnson Amendment
column7: the 1954 change in the U.S. tax code that prohibits church leaders from using the pulpit for political purposes.

column1: If we get those people to vote
column2: we're going to win in Virginia
column3: he said. ""If they don't vote
column4: it's not going to happen.""Trump also said ""we need help in Ohio
column5: the state where he held his Republican National Convention last month.Ohio Governor John Kasich
column6: who lost to Trump in the Republican primary race
column7: has refused to endorse Trump.""We're very close in Ohio
column8: but we need help

column1: Trump has seen a steady stream of moderate Republicans vow not to support him
column2: such as U.S. Senator Susan Collins of Maine
column3: and 50 Republican national security experts signed a letter opposing him. All this is evidence of fissures in the party over the bellicose rhetoric and positions of Trump
column4: who on Wednesday called Obama ""the founder of ISIS
column5: the acronym for Islamic State
column6: and Clinton ""the co-founder.""Trump joked that winning the White House and doing a good job as president might be his only way to salvation.""So go out and spread the words and once I get in
column7: I will do the thing that I do very well
column8: said Trump with a smile. ""I figure it's probably maybe the only way I'm going to get to heaven
column9: so I better do a good job."" (Reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Clinton'

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-garland-idUSKCN10M1WD	Clinton would stick with Garland as nominee for Supreme Court: Reid	"
By Ruthy Munoz and Doina Chiacu
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid said on Thursday he believed Hillary Clinton would stick with President Barack Obama's Supreme Court nominee if she won the Nov. 8 presidential election.Some Republican conservatives were concerned that if Democratic presidential candidate Clinton won the White House
column2: she would pick a more liberal judge than Obama's nominee
column3: Merrick Garland
column4: for a lifetime appointment to the high court. Garland is a centrist federal appeals court judge whom a number of Republicans have praised.""I would think that she and all the people around her would say
column5: 'Why do we need to rock the boat here? Let's get him confirmed quickly and move on to the next one
column6: whenever that comes
column7: '"" Reid said on a conference call with reporters.Clinton has urged the Senate to confirm Garland. Her  campaign did not immediately return a request for comment on Reid's remarks.

column1: Senate Democrats may try to force a vote on procedural motions that
column2: if successful
column3: would lead to a vote on Garland before the new president takes office in January
column4: Reid said. He invited along Republicans who want to distance themselves from their party's controversial presidential candidate
column5: Donald Trump.""We have a couple of options and we are deciding when to do that. And if we should do that. When and if
column6: Reid said.The leader of the Republican-controlled Senate
column7: Mitch McConnell
column8: has refused to schedule hearings on the nomination of Garland
column9: saying the winner of the Nov. 8 presidential election should choose the Supreme Court justice. Obama nominated Garland on March 16 to replace conservative Justice Antonin Scalia

column1: The majority leader has been clear: the next president will make the nomination for this vacancy
column2: Don Stewart
column3: deputy chief of staff for McConnell
column4: said in an email.A number of Republican senators in tough re-election fights are trying to distance themselves from their party's controversial nominee
column5: yet they refuse to hold a vote on Garland
column6: Reid said.

column1: He said those Republicans should call on McConnell to confirm Garland
column2: not hold the Supreme Court seat for someone as ""radical and unfit"" as Trump
column3: a New York businessman who has never held public office.""They spend a lot of time these Republicans
column4: spending a lot of energy trying to separate themselves from Donald Trump. But as long as they're holding a Supreme Court seat open for him
column5: they're his minions. They're his enablers
column6: Reid said.   (Writing by Doina Chiacu; editing by Grant McCool)"	['Reid'

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-taxes-idUSKCN10M1I7	Clinton to release 2015 tax returns within days
column2: criticizes Trump	"

column1: By Amanda Becker and Susan Heavey
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton will release her 2015 tax returns and her running mate
column2: U.S. Senator Tim Kaine and his wife
column3: Anne Holton
column4: will release the last 10 years of their tax returns within days
column5: according to a source close to Clinton.The returns will show Clinton paid an effective tax rate of 35 percent and gave about 10 percent to charity
column6: CNBC reported.The release comes as Republican Donald Trump is facing criticism for not releasing his tax returns - a political practice that is not required by law but has been done by every White House nominee since 1973.""He refuses to do what every other presidential candidate in decades has done and release his tax returns
column7: Clinton said on Thursday in an economic speech in Michigan.  Clinton's campaign has already released tax returns going back to 2007. In addition
column8: tax returns are publicly available for the eight years her husband
column10: was in the White House. Prior years were released by his campaign.

column1: Tax returns filed by the Clintons have been made public
column2: in some form
column3: for every year back to 1977.Trump
column4: a New York businessman
column5: has refused to release his tax returns
column6: saying they are under audit by the Internal Revenue Service. He has said he is unlikely to do so before the Nov. 8 presidential election. Critics
column7: including 2012 Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney
column8: have blasted Trump for failing to disclose his tax rate and raised questions about what his returns say about his net worth and various business ties

column1: Asked in a television interview in May what tax rate he pays
column2: Trump replied ""It's none of your business.""The IRS has said Trump can release his tax returns even while under audit. Besides showing sources and amounts of income
column3: tax returns show what percentage tax rate a person ultimately pays
column4: as well as how much they claimed in deductions and the amounts given to charities.

column1: Earlier this month
column2: at a Clinton rally in Omaha
column3: Nebraska
column4: billionaire investor Warren Buffett
column5: whose Berkshire Hathaway (BRKa.N) conglomerate is based there
column6: challenged Trump to make his returns public.""I'm under audit
column7: too
column8: and I would be delighted to meet him anyplace
column11: Buffett said. ""I'll bring my tax return
column12: he can bring his tax return ... and let people ask us questions.""Trump has declined to do so.  (Editing by Frances Kerry and Jonathan Oatis)"	['Kaine'

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-usa-idUSKCN10M1LG	U.S. House Democrats' Pelosi: administration may shift funds for Zika	"

WASHINGTON U.S. House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi said the Obama administration may announce as early as Thursday that it is shifting more money into fighting the Zika virus.""Maybe today or tomorrow
column2: Pelosi told reporters in a hallway on Thursday. She did not give an amount
column3: but said
column4: ""I think they are going to try to do it a piece at a time
column5: hoping that something else will happen
column6: an apparent reference to the administration's request that the Republican-led Congress approve a funding bill to combat the virus.The Obama administration in February requested $1.9 billion to fight the virus
column7: which was first detected in Brazil last year and has spread rapidly in the Americas. Before going home on summer recess
column8: lawmakers were discussing a $1.1 billion measure
column9: but the bill stalled amid partisan bickering.

column1: House Democrats at a news conference urged the Republicans to reconvene Congress to address the virus. Florida is grappling with at least 21 cases of locally transmitted Zika
column2: and the Obama administration has already reprogrammed nearly $600 million to fight the virus.But the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will spend all of its remaining funds by the end of September
column3: while two other agencies will exhaust their resources for Zika by the end of August
column4: Representative Rosa DeLauro said.

column1: Money will have to be shifted from biomedical research to fight Zika
column2: DeLauro said. ""If they don't
column3: vaccine development will be stopped dead in its tracks
column4: she said.

column1: (Reporting by Susan Cornwell; Editing by Phil Berlowitz and Jonathan Oatis)"	['DeLauro'
column2: 'Pelosi'
column3: 'Obama']	[]

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-isis-idUSKCN10M1S2	Clinton campaign calls Trump ISIS attack 'false claim'	"

WASHINGTON In response to Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's accusation that Democrat President Barack Obama and Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton were ""co-founders"" of Islamic State
column2: Clinton's campaign called the remarks a ""false claim."" ""This is another example of Donald Trump trash-talking the United States
column3: senior policy advisor Jake Sullivan said in a statement. ""What's remarkable about Trump's comments is that once again
column4: he's echoing the talking points of (Russian President Vladimir) Putin and our adversaries to attack American leaders and American interests
column5: while failing to offer any serious plans to confront terrorism or make this country more secure.""

column1: (Reporting by Ginger Gibson; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)"	['Sullivan'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-democrats-pelosi-idUSKCN10M1K7	U.S. House Democratic leader blames Russians for 'electronic Watergate'	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi on Thursday said the recent cyber attack on Democratic politicians was ""broad"" and that Russians were clearly behind the breach
column2: adding that the damage was still being investigated.""It is the Russians
column3: Pelosi told reporters at a news conference
column4: referring to the recent breach affecting the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. Pelosi called the attack
column5: made public last month
column6: an ""electronic Watergate"" akin to the 1972 burglary at Democratic Party headquarters at the Watergate office that upended the Nixon presidency. ""This is a break-in.""Pelosi's comments come on the heels of a New York Times report on Thursday that the cyber attack targeting Democrats was wider than first thought
column7: with more than 100 party officials and groups were affected.

column1: The Democratic National Committee and U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's campaign was also affected. Asked if she was personally targeted
column2: Pelosi said she did not know.""We are assessing the damage
column3: Pelosi told reporters
column4: adding that she could not speak to the impact on any Democratic governors.The Obama administration has not publicly named Russia as behind the attack
column5: but investigators have concluded the attackers were directed by the GRU
column6: Russia's military intelligence service
column7: and the FSB
column8: the civilian espionage agency. Clinton has also pointed to Moscow.

column1: Russia has denied involvement in the breach.A U.S. official familiar with the investigation said no evidence has been found so far that indicates the hackers got into Clinton's personal server or any classified systems
column2: but their footprints suggest they ""paid special attention to accounts they thought might lead them to information of national security interest.""

column1: The official said the hackers apparently proceeded beyond the Democratic National Committee
column2: the Clinton campaign
column3: and the Democrats' House of Representatives campaign committee to individual email accounts and probably other Democratic groups and individuals who emailed people using the accounts they first hacked.""The pattern fits what has come to be standard hacking practice
column4: said the official
column5: who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss an ongoing investigation by government as well as private agencies. ""You go as far as you can
column6: hoping you find something useful."" (Reporting by Susan Cornwell; Additional reporting by John Walcott; Writing by Susan Heavey; Editing by W Simon and Lisa Von Ahn)"	['Pelosi'
column7: 'Obama'
column8: 'Clinton'
